texts.definition: Sequences of storytelling where players cannot act.
markups: <style="Definition">Sequences of storytelling where players cannot act.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> are used when games cannot progress the entire game story through actions and events and need to give longer descriptions and explanations to players. These scenes are usually located between sections of gameplay that differ significantly, either because of change of location or type of activities required, or located right before a challenge to make players aware of the challenge.

<style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> are sometimes criticized in games because they remove agency for players. See Klejver for a discussion regarding the pros and cons of using <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> in games.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Early examples of games using Cutscenes include Pac-Man, which only used it for comical animations, and Donkey Kong, which used it forward a simple storyline. Later games such as Maniac Mansion used them more extensively to unfold narratives and the Dragon's Lair series paradoxically introduce interactivity into Cutscenes through the use of Quick Time Events. With the possibility of full motion video, games such the Myst series and the Wing Commander series started to use human actors to portray the game characters and this has been continued in the Command and Conquer series.

<style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> are often include in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-Based Roleplaying Games</link></style>, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mass%20Effect%20series">Mass Effect series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Witcher%20series">Witcher series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>. While players can interrupt the <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> that game masters provide in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Vampire:%20The%20Masquerade">Vampire: The Masquerade</link></style>, this does not affect the game state since it only updates as the game master wishes.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

The primary reason for using <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> are to convey information to players that they should not be able to miss, so designing <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> need to first and foremost make the presentation clearly describe this information and after that consider when it should be given to the players. The most common use of <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> are <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> but specific cases when they can be used regardless of how they progress <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> are transitions between <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> (the original use), enacting <style="Link"><link="surprise-attacks">Surprise Attacks</link></style> (enforcing players to "act" surprised by not letting them react), giving <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> of new <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, or depicting <style="Link"><link="quick-travel">Quick</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/One-Way%20Travel">One-Way Travel</link></style> (including some forms of <style="Link"><link="quick-returns">Quick Returns</link></style>). Common places for <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> are when players encounter new <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> so that they can be given <style="Link"><link="point-interest-indicators">Point of Interest Indicators</link></style>, or when they are supposed to experience <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>. The scenes can be used to show the presence of the two first, possibly as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style> events, while the last can be fully instantiated by <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style>. Another option (found e.g. in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout:%20New%20Vegas">Fallout: New Vegas</link></style>) is to provide <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> that tell what happened after the game has been completed - this can be used to make players realize the presence of <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destinies</link></style>. Since it may be difficult to time the suitability of when to enforce global <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, it is easier to time <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> to the events in the game in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> unless <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> are used. For this reason, <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> are more often applied to <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>.

One part of making the information in <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> difficult to miss is to not allow players to do anything else while they are taking place; this is most easily done by removing players ability to do actions (i.e. force them to do <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style>). The other part if fully control the presentation, this is easiest done through <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> playing animations, audio recordings, or video recordings. Alternatives to <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> include <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> or players in <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style> when they provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Effect%20Descriptions">Effect Descriptions</link></style> or engage in uninterrupted <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>. However, the <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> played do not have to be fully predetermined: having sets of <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> allows scenes to be chosen due to the current game state; using the game engine to run the <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> allows minor variations such as the positions of game elements; and using <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> allow <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> to be fully modulated with the game state and players.

<style="Link"><link="summary-updates">Summary Updates</link></style> are <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> which can either describe the context before a <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scene</link></style> or describe the consequences of the events that took place during a <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scene</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="quick-time-events">Quick Time Events</link></style> are another specific form of <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> that requires player input to show successful versions rather than unwanted ones. While this is somewhat of a paradox, these events very rarely have more than one 'correct' way of performing them, making them mainly a question of providing the right (and known in advance) input and timing that input precisely.

An alternative to <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Scripted%20Sequences">Scripted Sequences</link></style>, which allows players to affect the game state but not the part scripted.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> provide game designers with possibilities of having full control over how players perceive the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, including providing details about <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>,  <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style> that the ordinary gameplay could not. In fact, <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style> can exist only within <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> and still exist in a game's diegesis.

<style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> also allow players to be given views into <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> otherwise not possible, and can be used to make players realize these exist in situations where they have no ways of perceiving them through gameplay actions.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

As mentioned above, one of the main reasons for using <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> is to unfold <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. This may make players more aware of <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> by setting up the situation or stressing the importance of an upcoming choice, but may also ruin it by introducing <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> actions that players did not feel were appropriate to how they perceive the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. Simply not letting players have a choice even if the actions performed were plausible may also cause players to feel that there are no <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> in a game since the game design has predetermined the actions. Another reason for using <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> is that it can help players feel <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Identification">Identification</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> based on the narration and diegesis.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Automated%20Responses">Automated Responses</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> with localized <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, and one of the most controlled ways of doing <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style> to either present the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Realities</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> or unfold <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> to players. Of course, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> can be partly built from <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style>, so the patterns can instantiate each other. As events that take control of the game state completely, <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> are <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> which may cause <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style> for players but can guarantee that <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> is maintained. If they move players between different locations, <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> can functionally be <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style>. When the <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> only forward the narrative without changing the game state they can be said to be <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> stop gameplay, and game time for <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, and thereby are a form of <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style> which gives players <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> or sometimes <style="Link"><link="lull-periods">Lull Periods</link></style> depending on how interesting the players find the <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style>. Even so, they work against <style="Link"><link="minimalized-social-weight">Minimalized Social Weight</link></style> since they are designed to capture players attention with a story presentation. Even if they are made to be narratively interesting or contain gameplay information, they nearly always cause <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style> since they interrupt gameplay. The first time a particular <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cut%20Scenes">Cut Scene</link></style> is experienced it may be or include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> and this can be used to give <style="Link"><link="unpredictable-behavior">Unpredictable Behavior</link></style> to <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>.

When <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> involve players or other agents, they are examples of <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> that limit players' <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> and can change their perceptions of their <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>. They also enforce players to perform <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style> while they are taking place (even if their <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> are performing actions) - and this is true even if the <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> do not involve the players.

Given that <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> takes away players' agency the pattern is difficult to combine with given them an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>. However, <style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> may give <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> about how to meet future challenges, e.g. through <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style>, and may thereby function as <style="Link"><link="goal-indicators">Goal Indicators</link></style> and give players' a <style="Link"><link="determinable-chance-succeed">Determinable Chance to Succeed</link></style> - all which gives rise to <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Cutscenes</style> can make use of <style="Link"><link="first-person-views">First-Person</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="third-person-views">Third-Person</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="god-views">God Views</link></style> regardless of what a game in general uses, and this can be done for dramatic effects.

N/A
